header.title: THE MARTINIST review
authors: The Martinist Study and Research Group (Publisher)

central_thesis: This Martinist Review promotes and details a unified 'Martinist Operative and General Ritual' for worldwide practitioners, synthesizing both the 'Way of Heart' (Louis-Claude de Saint-Martin's 'Action Through Prayer') and the 'Operative Way' (Martinez Pasquales' 'Prayer and Operation'). The central aim of this 'common Work' is 'Universal Reintegration,' which involves individual and collective redemption and a return to the divine origin, utilizing the power of the Divine Name IESHOUAH and engaging with spiritual entities through a precise theurgical liturgy.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part 1. Introduction: Introductory Notes on the Divine Name IESHOUAH
structure_content.summary: This section introduces and explores the mystical significance of the Divine Name 'IESHOUAH' (Iod-He-SHIN-Vau-He) within Christian Kabbalah. It highlights the esoteric meaning of the letter SHIN's insertion into the Tetragrammaton, symbolizing the Incarnation of the Divine Word and the formation of the 'living Creature' (Man). The text contextualizes IESHOUAH within the works of historical occultists like Agrippa and Khunrath, asserting its role as a unifying factor for Martinists globally and acknowledging its reverence across diverse religious traditions.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part 2. The Martinist Operative and General Ritual
structure_content.summary: This part meticulously outlines the practical steps and components of the Martinist Operative and General Ritual. It covers preliminary requirements such as alimentary and sexual regimen, specific room conditions, and ceremonial clothing. The 'Sacramentary' details prayers for consecrating all ritual tools and vestments. The 'Ritual' section describes the sequence of invocations, prayers for various aspects of humanity and the spiritual hierarchy, the use of sacred fire and incense, and the process for dismissing celestial spirits, culminating in a comprehensive guide for conducting the Martinist monthly operation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part 3. Appendix: A Profile of Martinez Pasquales, his doctrine and his ORDER OF ELUS-COHEN
structure_content.summary: This appendix offers an in-depth profile of Don Martinez de Pasqually, the founder of the Order of Elus-Cohen. It clarifies the distinctions and shared objectives between Pasquales' 'Operative Way' (Prayer and Operation) and Saint-Martin's 'Way of Heart' (Action Through Prayer), both aiming for Universal Reintegration. The doctrine's core tenets, including the divine origin and fall of man, and the purpose of theurgical 'Works,' are elaborated. The section concludes by detailing the three distinctive elements of the Elus-Cohen technique: Exorcisms, Conjunctions, and Prayers, which together form their comprehensive 'Culte' or Divine Worship.

key_concepts.definition: Esoteric organizations stemming from the traditions of Louis-Claude de Saint-Martin and Martinez Pasquales, dedicated to spiritual work and the pursuit of Universal Reintegration.
The supreme goal in Martinism, signifying the process of individual and collective spiritual redemption, the recovery of the original divine state, and the return to the ultimate divine source.

The 'Pentagrammic Name' (Iod-He-SHIN-Vau-He), a central Divine Name in Martinist and Christian Kabbalah. Its significance lies in the insertion of the letter SHIN into the Tetragrammaton, symbolizing the Incarnation of the Divine Word and the formation of 'living Creature' (Man).

The method associated with Louis-Claude de Saint-Martin and the 'Way of Heart,' emphasizing inner guidance, contemplation, and introspective prayer as the primary means for spiritual development and connection to the divine.

The method associated with Martinez Pasquales and the 'Operative Way,' which combines prayer with explicit theurgic operations and ritual magic, including evocations, to interact with spiritual entities and facilitate reintegration.
Meaning 'Elect Priesthood,' this is the Order founded by Martinez Pasquales, known for its focus on operative theurgy and direct contact with the spiritual world as a means to achieve reintegration.

In the context of Martinez Pasquales' doctrine, 'Culte' refers to the 'Divine Worship' or specific liturgical system composed of Exorcisms, Conjunctions, and Prayers, structured into ten distinct 'Operations' aimed at various spiritual objectives.

A cross symbol (T or X), recognized as the cursive Hebrew Tau. It is traced on the forehead or in space during rituals, signifying salvation, resurrection (four proper), and incarnation (four inverted), and is believed to repel demonic forces.

Supernatural manifestations (e.g., optical phenomena, sparks, hieroglyphs of transient fire, apparitions) observed by the Operator during Elus-Cohen operations, signifying that invoked spiritual entities have obeyed and providing a 'sign of Reconciliation'.
In Martinez Pasquales' cosmology, this is the ultimate divine source from which all beings originally emanated and to which they seek to return through the process of reintegration.

practical_system.description: The 'Martinist Operative and General Ritual' is a comprehensive theurgical system designed for individual and collective spiritual work towards 'Universal Reintegration.' It integrates the contemplative approach of Louis-Claude de Saint-Martin with the operative magic of Martinez Pasquales. The system involves rigorous physical and mental preparation, a structured sequence of consecration prayers for all ritual elements, specific invocations leveraging the Divine Name IESHOUAH, incense offerings, symbolic movements around an altar, and extensive prayer cycles addressing various spiritual and earthly concerns. Its core mechanics include 'Exorcisms' to control adverse spirits, 'Conjunctions' to establish contact with benevolent entities, and 'Prayers' for divine grace and guidance, all forming a 'Culte' or divine worship aimed at regenerating the individual and the cosmos.
tools: Alb (white linen vestment, extending four fingers from the floor)
Cordelier (red silk or cotton rope, making two turns around the waist, with two 24-inch fringes)
Sandals (raffia for summer) or Woollen Socks (with cork/rubber sole for winter)
Operational Cloth (crimson red linen or silk, approx. 25 square inches, featuring an embroidered Martinist Pantacle, or a metal Jewel of the Order as a substitute)
Candlesticks (one for the Central Luminary, one smaller for the ordinary Candle)
Candles (pure beeswax or liturgical wax, minimum 30% beeswax)
Incense (pure OLIBANUM/frankincense, in tear-drop form, stored in a metal box or classic incense boat)

Poniard or Sword (with a cross-form hilt, flat double-edged pointed blade, ornaments displaying Martinist Pantacle or Temple of Solomon symbols; handle preferably wood/horn or covered with isolating braid)
Sanctuary Light (a small, dim luminary for initial room lighting)
rituals: Preliminary Regimen: Prescribes dietary moderation, abstention from excitants (coffee, tobacco), and sexual continence for at least 24 hours prior to operation. Defines appropriate room conditions (exclusively for study/meditation/prayer, well-ventilated, specific temperature, purified with incense if dining room used) and personal clothing (Alb, Cordelier, Sandals; removal of metallic objects, head uncovered).

Sacramentary: Prayers and actions for sanctifying ritual components. This includes the Alb and Cordelier (vestments), Sandals, the Operational Cloth and the ritual space, the Poniard or Sword, Ink (for drawing), and Incense.

General Ritual Sequence: Begins with lighting a dim sanctuary light, making the Sign of the Cross, and invoking Venerated Masters. Proceeds to light and consecrate an ordinary candle, then a Central Luminary. Involves lighting charcoal in the censer, making three turns around the altar while offering incense and specific prayers (for purity, deliverance, guidance). Follows with extensive prayer cycles addressing peace, unity, brothers, dignitaries, grand masters, universal spirituality, world peace, humanity (spared from calamities, elemental ravages, epidemics), fruits of the earth, departed souls (brothers, relatives, masters of the past, wandering souls, lured souls), the sick, and leaders of Christian and non-Christian nations. Concludes with prayers for debased spirits in mineral, vegetable, and animal kingdoms, exorcism of Demoniacal Spirits (including tracing the TAU sign), prayers for Prevaricated Spirits, and dismissal of Celestial Spirits, finally extinguishing the Central Luminary and 'knocking' the room's corners with the poniard while invoking divine glory.

Martinez Pasquales' Culte Operations (10 Kinds): Includes specific forms of 'Divine Worship' such as Culte of Expiation, General Particular Grace, Operative Culte against Devils, Culte against Prevarication and of Conservation, Culte against War, Culte of Opposition to the Enemies of the Divine Law, Culte to Procure the Descent of the Divine Spirit, Culte of Strengthening of Faith, Culte of Establishing the Divine Conciliating Spirit within Oneself, and Culte of Annual Dedication of all Operations to the Creator.

relevant_quotes.text: I have desired to do good but I have not desired to make noise, because I have felt that noise did no good, and that good made no noise.

The aim of this General Ritual is to permit Martinists of all initiatic degrees, dispersed thoughout the world, to unite their efforts by working together, at certain monthly periods, on their common Work; the UNIVERSAL REINTEGRATION.

Very little has been written in English on Martinism, but even less can be found concerning its Founder, Martinez Pasqualez and his Order of Elus-Cohen. The last part of this issue is, therefore, but a humble effort to fill in the gap.
It is to Martinez de Pasqually that I owe my introduction to the higher truths.

Martinez wanted to propound a doctrine which would explain the occult history of humanity, the divine origin of man and his fall, and to teach the means HOW man could regenerate himself... The final goal was to communicate with Christ and thus regain the lost Kingdom. The evocation of Christ would constitute the Great Work.

His "TREATISE ON THE REINTEGRATION OF BEINGS INTO THEIR FIRST ESTATE, VIRTUES, AND POWERS, BOTH SPIRITUAL AND DIVINE ", called in short : "Reintegration of Beings", has been the Gospels of the Order of the Elus-Cohen.
The technique of the Elus-Cohen of Martinez Pasquales consists of three distinctive elements : EXORCISMS, CONJURATIONS and PRAYERS.

critical_analysis.relevance: This document is highly relevant for understanding the historical continuum and practical application within the Martinist tradition. It uniquely synthesizes the contemplative 'Way of Heart' (Saint-Martin) with the operative theurgy of the 'Elus-Cohen' (Martinez Pasquales), offering a unified ritual path toward 'Universal Reintegration.' For academic researchers, it provides primary source material in English on a traditionally secretive lineage, elucidating the theoretical underpinnings and practical mechanics of Christian Kabbalah and theurgy. For practitioners, it serves as a detailed manual, bridging two major streams of Martinism and offering a comprehensive system for spiritual work.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of initiated Martinists of all degrees, globally dispersed, who seek a standardized ritual for collective work towards Universal Reintegration. Secondary audiences include academic researchers specializing in Western Esotericism, particularly Martinism, Christian Kabbalah, and ritual magic, as well as occult practitioners interested in theurgical systems and the historical development of esoteric orders.
